Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Variable Selection for Remedying the Effects of Uncontrolled Variation in Data Driven Predictions
Award.AbstractNarration:
In a project funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program of the Chemistry Division, Professors Steven Brown and Karl Booksh, both from the University of Delaware, and Professor Barry Lavine of Oklahoma State University, seek to improve mathematical and statistical modeling of real-time measurement of chemical species. This research is aimed at reducing the cost-of-ownership of calibration and classification models that have become increasingly common in process monitoring, quality assurance and quality-by-design applications by studying the ways in which these models fail and by searching for ways to stabilize the modeling. The broader impacts of this project include the improvements in efficiency and performance from improved and more reliable chemical models for production and quality assurance, as well as the training of graduate and undergraduate students in data analysis, a skill in very high demand.

This project is a collaborative effort aimed at investigating fundamental issues important to chemical modeling in modern measurement science: (1) stabilizing calibration and classification relationships in the presence of unexpected contributions, (2) making calibrations and classifications as robust as possible to additional sources of background, and (3) improving classification and calibration models measured over multiple instruments. Methods for automated identification of the portions of the chemical responses that best model the system are being investigated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has been a collaborative effort aimed at investigating fundamental issues important to chemical modeling.  Problems that have been investigated in this study included the modeling of the strain hardening modulus of 1-butene and 1-hexene polyethylene (PE) copolymers, improving the performance of both classification and calibration models through variable selection, and the application of Raman and infrared spectroscopy to discriminate edible oils by variety for the purposes of authentication and the detection of adulterants.  The edible oil analyses in this work highlight the need for classification and adulteration studies that span multiple sources within each edible oil type.  The supplier to supplier variation for edible oils (and potentially seasonal variation within a supplier) is often greater than within supplier variation and may be comparable in some instances to differences between the average spectra of the different varieties of edible oils. This work also demonstrates that previous studies (which rely on only one source for each variety of edible oil) provide an overly optimistic estimate of the ability to spectroscopically classify edible oils as to variety or to detect low levels of adulterants in edible oils. All of the work performed in this project has been aimed at finding methods to improve the classification or calibration of Raman and infrared spectra through variable selection.  We have also attempted to obviate the effects of unmodeled variation present in data during model development thereby improving data classifications and have collected an infrared spectral data set that allows us to consider and to control for these effects.The broader impacts of this project include the improvements in efficiency and performance from improved and more reliable chemical models for production and quality assurance, as well as the training of graduate and undergraduate students in data analysis, a skill in very high demand.
